scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Chandler and Rachel are sitting on the couch.]

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (reading the comics) Eh..., I don’t, I don’t know.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Well, as old as he is in dog years, do you think Snoopy should still be allowed to fly this thing?

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: Rachel?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: Do you remember when you first came here, how you spent two weeks getting trained by another waitress?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Oh, sure! Do you need me to train somebody new?

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: (laughs) Good one. Actually, ah, Terry wants you to take the training again, whenever.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: (to Chandler) Eh, do you believe that?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (thinks about it) Yeah?

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Chandler and Rachel are sitting on the couch.]

events.event_description: Chandler reads a comic book and questions whether Snoopy should still be allowed to fly his doghouse, indicating a humorous reflection.
Gunther addresses Rachel, recalling her initial two-week training period as a waitress at Central Perk.
Rachel responds affirmatively, offering to train a new waitress if needed.
Gunther jokes about Rachel's training, then informs her that Terry wants her to undergo training again.
Rachel asks Chandler if he believes Gunther's statement about her training, seeking his opinion.
Chandler considers Rachel's question and agrees that he believes Gunther's statement.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: The hallway of Ross’s building, there is a Brown Bird girl selling
cookies, as Ross and Chandler come up the stairs.]

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: So that’s two boxes of the Holiday Macaroons. On behalf of the Brown Birds of America, I salute you. (Does the Brown Bird salute, she blows on a bird call, then holds her hand, palm facing out, next to her face, and then waves it like a bird flapping it’s wings.)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Just admit it Chandler, you have no backhand.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Excuse me little one, I have a very solid backhand.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Shielding your face and shrieking like a girl... is not a backhand.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I was shrieking... like a Marine.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: All right here. Watch me execute the three ‘P’s of championship play. Power. (swings the racquet) Precision. (swings the racquet.) and penache. (does a backswing and hits Sarah who’s started up the stairs, knocking her down, they both watch in horror.)

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: The hallway of Ross’s building, there is a Brown Bird girl selling
cookies, as Ross and Chandler come up the stairs.]

events.event_description: Sarah sells two boxes of Holiday Macaroons to Ross and Chandler, salutes the Brown Birds of America, blows a bird call, and waves her hand like a bird flapping its wings.
Ross comments to Chandler that he has no backhand.
Chandler responds to Ross, claiming he has a very solid backhand.
Ross criticizes Chandler for shielding his face and shrieking like a girl, implying it is not a backhand.
Chandler defends himself, saying he was shrieking like a Marine.
Ross demonstrates executing the three 'P's of championship play: Power, Precision, and Penache, by swinging his racquet three times.
Ross hits Sarah with his racquet during his demonstration, knocking her down as she starts up the stairs.
Ross and Chandler watch in horror as Ross's racquet hits Sarah and knocks her down.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Central Perk, the gang’s all there discussing the incident.]

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: You broke a little girl’s leg?!!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I know. I feel horrible. Okay.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (reading the paper) Says here that a muppet got whacked on Seasame Street last night. (to Ross) Where exactly were around ten-ish?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well, I’m gonna go see her. I want to bring her something, what do you think she’ll like?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Maybe a Hello Kitty doll, the ability to walk...

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I’m gonna get back to retraining. (gets up)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: All right, see you guys. (starts to leave)

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Look out kids, he’s coming! (Ross continues to leave with his head down in shame.)

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: And I gotta go sell some Christmas trees.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Have fun. Oh wait, no, don’t! I forgot I am totally against that now.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: What? Me having a job?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: No, no, I am against innocent trees being cut down in their prime, and their, their corpses grotesquely dressed in like tinsel and twinkly lights. (to Joey) Hey, how do you sleep at night?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well, I’m pretty tired from lugging the trees around all day. Hey, Phoebe listen, you got this all wrong. Those trees were born to be Christmas trees, their fulfilling their life purpose, by, by making people happy.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yes. Yes, and ah, ah, the trees are happy too, because for most of them, it’s the only chance to see New York.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: ...and after you’ve delivered the drinks, you take the empty tray....

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Gunther, Gunther, please, I’ve worked here for two and a half years, I know the empty trays go over there. (points to the counter.)

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: What if you put them here. (sets the empty tray on another stack of empty trays on the back counter.)

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Huh. Well, y'know that’s actually a really good idea, because that way they’ll be closer to the mugs. Y'know what, you should have the other waitresses do that too.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: They already do. That’s why they call it the ‘tray spot.’

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Gee, I always heard them talk about that, I just always thought that it was a club they went to. Oh God, I’m, I’m sorry. (walks away)

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: It’s all right. Sweetheart.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Central Perk, the gang’s all there discussing the incident.]

events.event_description: Chandler reads a newspaper and mentions that a muppet was harmed on Sesame Street last night.
Ross expresses his intention to visit a girl who was injured, asking for gift suggestions.
Monica suggests giving the girl a Hello Kitty doll and sarcastically mentions the ability to walk.
Rachel announces her plan to return to retraining, then leaves the scene.
Ross departs from Central Perk with his head down, indicating shame.
Joey announces he is going to sell Christmas trees.
Phoebe expresses her opposition to cutting down trees for Christmas.
Joey defends selling Christmas trees by stating they are fulfilling their life purpose.
Chandler explains that most Christmas trees are happy because it's their only chance to see New York.
Rachel corrects Gunther about the placement of empty trays and suggests a better system.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Sarah’s bedroom, her room is decorated with a space motif.]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: So, this must be kinda neat for ya, huh? I mean, your Dad tells me that you get a couple of days off school, and you, you ah, don’t have to sell those cookies anymore.

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: Well, I kinda wanted to sell the cookies. The girl who sells the most wins a trip to Spacecamp, and gets to sit in a real space shuttle.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Wow, you ah, you really like all this space stuff, huh?

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: Yeah. My Dad says if I spend as much time helping him clean apartments, as I do daydreaming about outer space, he’d be able to afford a trip to the Taj Mahal.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I think you would have to clean a whole lot of apartments to go all the way to India.

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: No. The one in Atlantic City, Dad loves the slots. He says he’s gonna double the college money my Grandma left me.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Huh. Well, good luck to Dad. Say, how many more boxes would you have to sell in order to win?

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: The girl who won last year sold four hundred and seventy-five.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: So far, I’ve sold seventy-five.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Four hundred, huh? Well, that sounds do-able. (starts to get out his wallet) How much are the boxes?

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: Five dollars a box.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: (puts away his wallet) And what is second prize?

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: A ten speed bike. But, I’d rather have something my Dad couldn’t sell.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well, that makes sense.

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: Could you do me one favor, if it’s not too much trouble?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Yeah, Sarah, anything.

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: Could you pull open the curtains for me? The astronauts from the space shuttle are gonna be on the news, and since we don’t have a TV, the lady across the alley said she’d push hers up to a window, so I could watch it.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Sarah’s bedroom, her room is decorated with a space motif.]

events.event_description: Ross comments to Sarah that she has days off school and no longer needs to sell cookies.
Sarah explains her motivation to sell cookies is to win a trip to Spacecamp and sit in a space shuttle.
Ross comments on Sarah's interest in space and her father's comment about her helping him clean apartments.
Sarah states her father wants to go to the Taj Mahal using money from her grandmother's inheritance.
Sarah mentions her father plans to double her grandmother's college money by gambling at slots in Atlantic City.
Sarah asks how many boxes she needs to sell to win the trip, referencing last year's winner.
Sarah states she has sold seventy-five boxes so far.
Ross calculates that Sarah needs to sell 400 more boxes and asks about the price per box.
Sarah explains that each box costs five dollars.
Sarah asks Ross to open the curtains so she can watch the space shuttle news on her neighbor's TV.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: A hallway, Ross is selling Brown Bird cookies for Sarah, he stops and knocks on
a door.]

dialogue.speaker: WOMAN
dialogue.text: (looking through her peephole, we see Ross standing in the hallway.) Yesss?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hi, I’m selling Brown Bird cookies.

dialogue.speaker: WOMAN
dialogue.text: You’re no Brown Bird, I can see you through my peephole.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: No, hi, I’m, I’m an honorary Brown Bird (does the Brown Bird salute.)

dialogue.speaker: WOMAN
dialogue.text: What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Ah, well, it means that I can sell cookies, but I’m not invited to sleep-overs.

dialogue.speaker: WOMAN
dialogue.text: I can dial 9-1-1 at the touch of a button, y'know. Now, go away!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: No, please, please, um, it’s for a poor little girl who wants to go to Spacecamp more than anything in the world.

dialogue.speaker: WOMAN
dialogue.text: I’m pressing, a policeman is on his way.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Okay, okay! I’m going. I’m going. (goes across the hall to knock on another door.)

dialogue.speaker: WOMAN
dialogue.text: I can still see you!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: All right!!

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: A hallway, Ross is selling Brown Bird cookies for Sarah, he stops and knocks on
a door.]

events.event_description: Ross stands in the hallway and knocks on a door.
Woman looks through her peephole and sees Ross standing in the hallway.
Woman responds to Ross from inside her apartment, asking 'Yesss?'
Ross introduces himself as selling Brown Bird cookies.
Woman comments that Ross is not a Brown Bird and can see him through her peephole.
Ross claims he is an honorary Brown Bird and performs the Brown Bird salute.
Woman asks Ross what being an honorary Brown Bird means.
Ross explains that he can sell cookies but is not invited to sleep-overs.
Woman threatens to dial 9-1-1 and tells Ross to go away.
Ross pleads that his visit is for a girl who wants to go to Spacecamp and begins to leave.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: (walking up to Joey) Hey.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey. What, what are you doing here?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Well, I-I thought a lot about what you said, and um, I realilized duh, all right maybe I was a little judgmental. Yeah, (looks at the tree) oh, but oh...

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Look now, Phoebe remember, hey, their just fulfilling their Christmas....

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Destiny.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Sure.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Okay. (One of Joey’s co-workers, walks by with a dead tree.) Yikes! That one doesn’t look very fulfilled.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Oh, that’s, that’s ah, one of the old ones, he’s just taking it to the back.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: You keep the old ones in the back, that is so ageist.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well we have to make room for the fresh ones.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: So, what happens to the old guys?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well, they go into the chipper.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Why, do I have a feeling that’s not as happy as it sounds? (Joey points out one going into the chipper to her, as this haunty, demonic music starts to play in the background) No! Nooooo!!! (she winces in horror and hides her face against Joey’s shoulder, as she sees the tree spit out from the chipper.)

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: (to the guy operating the chipper) Hey! Hey!! (makes the ‘cut it’ motion with his hands)

events.event_description: Phoebe approaches Joey at his Christmas tree stand and greets him.
Phoebe reflects on her previous judgments about Christmas trees and comments on the appearance of a tree.
Joey explains that the old Christmas trees are taken to the back to make room for new ones.
Phoebe questions what happens to the old trees, suggesting they are chipped.
Joey confirms that old trees are sent into the chipper.
Phoebe reacts with horror upon seeing a tree being fed into the chipper and hides her face.
Joey signals to the operator of the chipper to stop or slow down the machine.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: Central Perk, all except Phoebe are there, Ross is telling the gang, minus
Rachel who’s still being retrained, about the different cookie options.]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: ...and these come in the shapes of your favourite Christmas characters, Santa, Rudolph, and Baby Jesus.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: All right, I’ll take a box of the cream filled Jesus’s.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, one box! Come on, I’m trying to send a little girl to Spacecamp, I’m putting you down for five boxes. Chandler, what about you?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Ahh, do you have any coconut flavoured deities?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: No, but ah, there’s coconut in the Hanukkah Menoreoes. I tell you what, I’ll put you down for eight boxes, one for each night.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Mon?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: All right, I’ll take one box of the mint treasures, just one, and that’s it. I-I started gaining weight after I joined the Brown Birds. (to Ross) Remember, how Dad bought all my boxes and I ate them all?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Ah, no Mon, Dad had to buy everyone of your boxes because you ate them all. But ah, y'know I’m sure that’s not gonna happen this time, why don’t I put you down for three of the mint treasures and just a couple of the Rudolph’s.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh, come on, now you know you want ‘em.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Don’t, don’t, don’t, don’t, don’t do this.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I’ll tell you what Mon, I’ll give you the first box for free.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (she reaches out for it and stops) Oh God! I gotta go! (runs out)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Come on! All the cool kids are eating ‘em! (chases after her.)

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: And when you have a second later, I wanna show you why we don’t just trap spiders under coffee mugs and leave them there.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: (sitting down next to Chandler) I’m training to be better at a job that I hate, my life officially sucks.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Look Rach, wasn’t this supposed to a temporary thing? I thought you wanted to do fashion stuff?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well, yeah! I’m still pursuing that.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: How... exactly are you pursuing that? Y'know other than sending out resumes like what, two years ago?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well, I’m also sending out.... good thoughts.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: If you ask me, as long as you got this job, you’ve got nothing pushing you to get another one. You need the fear.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: The fear?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: He’s right, if you quit this job, you then have motivation to go after a job you really want.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well then how come you’re still at a job that you hate, I mean why don’t you quit and get ‘the fear’?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Because, I’m too afraid.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I don’t know, I mean I would give anything to work for a designer, y'know, or a buyer.... Oh, I just don’t want to be 30 and still work here.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Yeah, that’d be much worse than being 28, and still working here.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: Rachel?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: Remind me to review with you which pot is decaf and which is regular.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Can’t I just look at the handles on them?

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: You would think.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Okay, fine. Gunther, y'know what, I am a terrible waitress, do you know why I’m a terrible waitress? Because, I don’t care. I don’t care. I don’t care which pot is regular and which pot is decaf, I don’t care where the tray spot is, I just don’t care, this is not what I want to do. So I don’t think I should do it anymore. I’m gonna give you my weeks notice.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: What?!

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Gunther, I quit.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (to Joey) Does this mean we’re gonna have to start paying for coffee? (Joey shrugs his shoulders.)

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: Central Perk, all except Phoebe are there, Ross is telling the gang, minus
Rachel who’s still being retrained, about the different cookie options.]

events.event_description: Ross describes cookie options shaped like Christmas characters to the gang.
Joey orders a box of cream-filled Jesus cookies.
Ross increases Joey's order to five boxes to support sending a girl to Spacecamp.
Chandler asks if there are coconut-flavored deities in the cookies.
Ross informs Chandler that there are coconut in Hanukkah Menoreoes and assigns him eight boxes.
Monica declines to take any cookies and runs out after expressing concern about gaining weight.
Ross chases after Monica to persuade her to take cookies.
Gunther mentions wanting to show why spiders shouldn't be trapped under coffee mugs.
Rachel expresses her dissatisfaction with her job and her desire to work in fashion.
Rachel announces her resignation from her waitress job to Gunther.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Chandler is entering numbers on a calculator as Ross reads
off how much he’s sold.]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: ....and 12, 22, 18, four... (Chandler starts laughing) What?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I spelled out boobies.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (comes up and starts looking through Ross’s cookie supply) Ross, but me down for another box of the mint treasures, okay. Where, where are the mint treasures?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Ah, we’re out. I sold them all.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Monica, I’m cutting you off.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: No. No, just, just, just a couple more boxes. It-it-it’s no big deal, all right, I’m-I’m cool. You gotta help me out with a couple more boxes!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Mon, look at yourself. You have cookie on your neck.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (covers her neck) Oh God! (runs to the bathroom)

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: So, how many have you sold so far?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Check this out. Five hundred and seventeen boxes!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Oh my God, how did you do that?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Okay, the other night I was leaving the museum just as ‘Laser Floyd’ was letting out of the planetarium, without even trying I sold 50 boxes! That’s when it occurred to me, the key to my success, ‘the munchies.’ So I ah, started hitting the NYU dorms around midnight. I am selling co

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: (entering) Okay, stop what you’re doing, I need envelope stuffers, I need stamp lickers.....

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well hey, who did these resumes for ya?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Me! On my computer.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well you sure used a large font.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Eh, yeah, well ah, waitress at a coffee shop and cheer squad co-captain only took up so much room.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Hey-hey-hey that’s funny! Your funny Chandler! Your a funny guy! You wanna know what else is really funny?!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Something else I might have said?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I don’t know, I don’t know, weren’t you the guy that told me to quit my job when I had absolutely nothing else to do. Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha!!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Sweetie, calm down, it’s gonna be okay.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: No, it’s not gonna be okay Ross, tomorrow is my last day, and I don’t have a lead. Okay, y'know what, I’m just gonna, I’m just gonna call Gunther and I’m gonna tell him, I’m not quitting.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You-you-you don’t wanna give into the fear.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: You and your stupid fear. I hate your fear. I would like to take you and your fear....

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: (entering, interrupting Rachel) Hey! I got great news!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Run, Joey! Run for your life! (runs out)

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: What? Rachel, listen, have you ever heard of Fortunata Fashions?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well my old man is doing a plumbing job down there and he heard they have an opening. So, you want me to see if I can get you an interview?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Oh my God! Yes, I would love that, oh, that is soo sweet, Joey.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Not a problem.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: And now for the great news.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: What, that wasn’t the great news?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Only if you think it’s better than this... (holds up an aerosol can) snow-in-a-can!! I got it at work. Mon, you want me to decorate the window, give it a kind of Christmas lookie.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Christmas cookie?

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Chandler is entering numbers on a calculator as Ross reads
off how much he’s sold.]

events.event_description: Ross reads off the number of cookie boxes he has sold, starting with '12, 22, 18, four...'
Chandler laughs after Ross spells out 'boobies' on the calculator
Monica begins looking through Ross's cookie supply and asks about the mint treasures
Ross informs Monica that the mint treasures are sold out and he is cutting her off from more sales
Monica covers her neck with cookie residue and runs to the bathroom after realizing she has cookie on her neck
Chandler asks Ross how many boxes he has sold so far, and Ross responds with 'Five hundred and seventeen'
Ross explains that he sold 50 boxes after leaving the museum and started selling at NYU dorms around midnight
Rachel enters the scene and demands envelope stuffers and stamp lickings from the others
Rachel confronts Chandler about a previous comment, accusing him of telling her to quit her job when she had nothing else to do
Joey enters the scene and offers to help Rachel get an interview at Fortunata Fashions, mentioning his father's plumbing job there

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Joey work, Joey is showing a guy a tree.]

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Okay, and ah, this one here is a Douglas Fir, now it’s a little more money, but you get a nicer smell.

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: Looks good. I’ll take it.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: (running up carrying a tree) Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait! No, no, you don’t want that one. No, you can have this cool brown one. (points to the almost dead tree she has)

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: It’s-it’s-it’s almost dead!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Okay but that’s why you have to buy it, so it can fulfil it’s Christmas destiny, otherwise there gonna throw it into the chipper. Tell him, Joey

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Yeah, the ah, trees that don’t fulfil their Christmas destiny are thrown in the chipper.

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: I-I think I’m gonna look around a little bit more.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Pheebs, you gotta stop this, I working on commission here.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (entering) Hey, guys. I’m here to pick out my Christmas tree.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Well look no further, (shows her the dead one) this one’s yours! Ahhh.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Is this the one that I threw out last year?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: All right y'know what, nevermind! Everyone wants to have a green one! I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to get so emotional, I guess it’s just the holidays, it’s hard.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Oh honey, is that ‘cause your Mom died around Christmas?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh, I wasn’t even thinking about that.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Oh. (turns and looks at Joey, who gives a ‘way-to-go’ thumbs up and smile.)

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Joey work, Joey is showing a guy a tree.]

events.event_description: Joey introduces a Douglas Fir tree to a customer, explaining its smell and price.
Phoebe runs up carrying a nearly dead tree and offers it to the customer, claiming it can fulfill its Christmas destiny.
Phoebe persuades the customer to buy the almost dead tree by saying it needs to fulfill its Christmas destiny or be thrown into the chipper.
Joey reminds the customer that trees not fulfilling their Christmas destiny are thrown into the chipper.
The customer decides to look around more and leaves to browse other trees.
Joey expresses frustration to Phoebe about her interfering with his sales commission.
Monica enters the scene announcing she is there to pick out her Christmas tree.
Phoebe shows Monica a dead tree, claiming it is her Christmas tree.
Monica questions if the dead tree is the same one she threw out last year.
Phoebe becomes emotional about the dead tree and the holidays, apologizing to Monica.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: A Brown Bird meeting, Ross is there with the other Brown Birds to see who won
the contest.]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: (to the girl sitting next to him) Hi there. How many, how many ah, did you sell?

dialogue.speaker: GIRL
dialogue.text: I’m not gonna tell you! You’re the bad man who broke Sarah’s leg.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hey now! That was an accident, okay.

dialogue.speaker: GIRL
dialogue.text: You’re a big scrud.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: What’s a scrud?

dialogue.speaker: GIRL
dialogue.text: Why don’t you look in the mirror, scrud.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I don’t have too. I can just look at you.

dialogue.speaker: LEADER
dialogue.text: All right girls, and man. Let’s see your final tallies. (all the girls raise their hands) Ohhhh, Debbie, (looks at her form) 321 boxes of cookies, (to Debbie) Very nice.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: (to himself) Not nice enough.

dialogue.speaker: LEADER
dialogue.text: Charla, 278. Sorry, dear, but still good.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: (to himself) Good for a scrud.

dialogue.speaker: LEADER
dialogue.text: Oh, yes Elizabeth. Ah, 871.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: That’s crap!! Sister Brown Bird. (to Elizabeth) Good going. (does the salute)

dialogue.speaker: LEADER
dialogue.text: Who’s next? (goes over and stands behind Ross, who’s feverishly writing on his form, and clears her throat to get his attention.)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hi there!

dialogue.speaker: LEADER
dialogue.text: Hi. And batting for Sarah, Ross Geller, 872. Although, it looks like you bought an awful lot of cookies yourself.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Um, that is because my doctor says that I have a very serious.... nuget.... diffency.

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: A Brown Bird meeting, Ross is there with the other Brown Birds to see who won
the contest.]

events.event_description: Ross greets the girl sitting next to him and asks about her cookie sales.
The girl accuses Ross of being the 'bad man' who broke Sarah's leg.
Ross denies breaking Sarah's leg, claiming it was an accident.
The girl insults Ross, calling him a 'scrud'.
Ross questions the meaning of 'scrud'.
The girl tells Ross to look in the mirror to see what a 'scrud' is.
The leader announces the final cookie tallies for the girls, calling out Debbie's score.
Ross comments to himself that Debbie's score is 'not nice enough'.
The leader announces Charla's score, and Ross comments that it is 'good for a scrud'.
The leader announces Elizabeth's score, and Ross exclaims that it is 'crap', then congratulates Elizabeth and salutes her.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Chandler, Phoebe, and Ross are there.]

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Tell us what happened, Brown Bird Ross.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well, I lost. Some little girl loaned her uniform to her nineteen year old sister, who went down to the U.S.S. Nimitz, and sold over 2,000 boxes.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (to Rachel, who’s entering) Hey! How’d the interview go?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Oh, I blew it. I wouldn’t of even hired me.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh, come here sweetie, listen, you’re gonna go on like a thousand interviews before you get a job. (she glares at him) That’s not how that was supposed to come out.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: This is the worst Christmas ever.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Y'know what Rach, maybe you should just, y'know stay here at the coffee house.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I can’t! It’s too late! Terry already hired that girl over there. (points to her) Look at her, she’s even got waitress experience. Last night she was teaching everybody how to make napkin.... (starts to cry) swans.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: That word was swans.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Chandler, Phoebe, and Ross are there.]

events.event_description: Chandler asks Ross to tell what happened, referring to him as 'Brown Bird Ross'.
Ross explains that a little girl loaned her uniform to her nineteen-year-old sister, who then went to the U.S.S. Nimitz and sold over 2,000 boxes.
Chandler asks Rachel how her interview went as she enters the scene.
Rachel responds that she blew the interview and wouldn't have even been hired.
Ross comforts Rachel, telling her she will go on many interviews before getting a job, but Rachel glares at him.
Phoebe states that this is the worst Christmas ever.
Chandler suggests that Rachel should stay at the coffee house instead of looking for a job.
Rachel says she can't stay because Terry has already hired another girl, pointing to her and mentioning her waitress experience.
Rachel starts to cry while describing the other girl teaching everyone how to make napkin swans.
Ross corrects Rachel, clarifying that the word she used was 'swans'.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: The hallway between the two apartments, Chandler, Phoebe, Ross, and Rachel are
coming up the stairs.]

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Well seeing that drunk Santa wet himself, really perked up my Christmas.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh! Oh my God!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY AND MONICA
dialogue.text: (jumping up from behind the couch) Merry Christmas!!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: You saved them! You guys! Oh God, you’re the best!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: It’s like ‘Night of the Living Dead Christmas Trees.’

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: (answering the phone) Hello? (listens) Yeah, this is she. (listens) Oh! You’re kidding! You’re kidding! (listens) Oh thank you! I love you!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Sure, everybody loves a kidder.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: (hanging up the phone) I got the job!

dialogue.speaker: ALL
dialogue.text: That’s great! Hey! Excellent!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh, God bless us, everyone.

scenes.location: The hallway between the two apartments
scenes.event_description:
[Scene: The hallway between the two apartments, Chandler, Phoebe, Ross, and Rachel are
coming up the stairs.]

events.event_description: Chandler comments that seeing a drunk Santa wet himself made his Christmas more lively.
Phoebe reacts with surprise and exclaims, 'Oh! Oh my God!'
Joey and Monica jump up from behind the couch and shout 'Merry Christmas!'
Phoebe expresses gratitude, saying 'You saved them! You guys! Oh God, you’re the best!'
Chandler humorously compares the scene to 'Night of the Living Dead Christmas Trees.'
Rachel answers the phone and listens to the caller, reacting with surprise and gratitude.
Rachel exclaims 'Oh! You’re kidding! You’re kidding!' upon hearing the good news.
Rachel hangs up the phone and announces she got the job.
All characters present cheer and express happiness about Rachel's news.
Phoebe wishes everyone a joyful holiday with the phrase 'Oh, God bless us, everyone.'

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Rachel is serving her last cup of coffee.]

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Here we go. I’m serving my last cup of coffee. (the gang starts humming the graduation theme) There you go. (hands it to Chandler) Enjoy. (they all cheer)

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (to Ross) Should I tell her I ordered tea?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Um, excuse me, everyone. Ah, this is my last night working here, and I ah, just wanted say that I made some really good friends working here, and ah, it’s just time to move on. (at the counter Gunther starts to cry and runs into the back room) Ah, and no offence to everybody who ah, still works here, you have no idea how good it feels to say that as of this moment I will never have to make coffee again.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Rachel is serving her last cup of coffee.]

events.event_description: Rachel serves her last cup of coffee to the gang at Central Perk.
The gang starts humming the graduation theme in response to Rachel serving coffee.
Rachel hands the last cup of coffee to Chandler and tells him to enjoy it.
The gang cheers in response to Rachel's last serving.
Chandler asks Ross if he should tell Rachel he ordered tea.
Ross responds with a simple 'No' to Chandler's question.
Rachel announces to everyone that it is her last night working at Central Perk and expresses her feelings about leaving.
Gunther starts crying and runs into the back room upon hearing Rachel's announcement.
Rachel states that she will never have to make coffee again, expressing relief and finality.
Rachel addresses the group, acknowledging her friendships and her decision to move on from her job.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Rachel’s new job, Rachel’s boss is telling her what to do.]

dialogue.speaker: S BOSS
dialogue.text: Now Mr. Kaplan Sr. likes his coffee strong, so your gonna use two bags instead of one, see. Now pay attention, ‘cause this part’s tricky, see some people use filters just once.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Rachel’s new job, Rachel’s boss is telling her what to do.]

events.event_description: Rachel's boss instructs her to use two coffee bags instead of one to make Mr. Kaplan Sr.'s coffee strong.
S BOSS emphasizes the importance of paying attention to the tricky part of the coffee preparation.
S BOSS explains that some people reuse coffee filters only once.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: The hallway between the apartments, Ross is bringing Sarah to Joey and
Chandler’s.]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I’m, I’m sorry you didn’t get to go to Spacecamp, and I’m hoping that maybe somehow, this may make up for it. Presenting Sarah Tuttle’s Private Very Special Spacecamp!! (opens the door and Chandler and Joey jump up, their apartment is decorated like outer space, one of the leather chairs is covered in tinfoil.)

dialogue.speaker: SARAH
dialogue.text: Really Mr. Geller, you don’t have to do this.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh come on! Here we go! (picks her up and puts her in the chair) Stand by for mission countdown!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: (simulating an echo) Ten , ten.., nine , nine, nine...., eight, eight, eight... (Chandler hits him in the back of the head) Okay, Blast off!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: I’m an alien. I’m an alien.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh no! An asteroid! (throws the soccer ball off the back of Joey’s head.)

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: The hallway between the apartments, Ross is bringing Sarah to Joey and
Chandler’s.]

events.event_description: Ross introduces Sarah to Chandler and Joey by bringing her into the decorated apartment.
Ross apologizes to Sarah for her missing out on Spacecamp and offers to make it up to her with a space-themed surprise.
Ross opens the door to the apartment, revealing the space-themed decorations.
Chandler and Joey jump up from their seats upon seeing the decorated apartment.
Ross places Sarah into a chair and announces a mission countdown.
Joey simulates an echo countdown from ten to eight, counting down aloud.
Chandler declares himself as an alien during the space-themed game.
Chandler and Joey react to the space-themed scenario, with Joey exclaiming 'Blast off!'.
Ross reacts to an imaginary asteroid by throwing a soccer ball at Joey's head.
